question: What is the primary objective of the Design & Construction project for the Special Steel Bridge across the Narmada River under Contract Package 15B?
ground_truth: The primary objective of the Design & Construction project for the Special Steel Bridge across the Narmada River under Contract Package 15B is the design and construction of a special steel bridge involving bridge structure, approaches of 200m length from abutments on both sides in formation in embankments with RUB, guide bunds, and protection works including testing and commissioning on a design-build lump sum price basis for the JNPT-Vadodara section of the Western Dedicated Freight Corridor (Phase 2).

question: What is the main scope of the CTP-15B project, which involves the design and construction of the Special Steel Bridge across the Narmada River, as part of the Western Dedicated Freight Corridor under Phase-2?
ground_truth: The main scope of Package CTP-15B is the design and construction of a Special Steel Bridge across the Narmada River, involving the bridge structure, approaches (of 200m length from abutments on both sides) in formation in embankments with 01 No. RUB, guide bunds, and protection works. The length of the proposed Narmada Steel Bridge is 1.4 km.
contexts:
Hereinafter referred as ‘Report Month’).

BRIEF SUMMARY OF PROJECT:

The main scope of Package CTP-15B is Design and Construction of Special Steel Bridge across Narmada River involving Bridge Structure, Approaches (of 200m Length from Abutments on Both Sides) in formation in Embankments with 01 No. RUB, Guide Bunds and protection works. The Length of the Proposed Narmada Steel Bridge is 1.4 Km. It is located in JNPT-Vadodara Section of Western Dedicated Freight Corridor under Phase-2. One No. RUB is a box type RUB which is a part of Bridge Approach on North Side of Alignment (Bharuch Side).

The Package CTP-15B is a small Portion across River Narmada, with a track Alignment of CTP-13 as an Interfacing Package. Good Amount of the Alignment of DFCC for Phase-2 is planned parallel to current Track of Indian Railways.

Our CTP-15B Project is passing through Sec-4, which is on detour side of Alignment, passing through Sarfuddin Village on Ankleshwar Side to Kukarwada Village on Bharuch Side, across River Narmada.

PROJECT SCOPE:

As per Contractual Data, the Portion of CTP-15B comprises of Two Nos. of Bridges. The Main Special Steel Bridge is denoted as Bridge No. 57 which is categorised as IMPORTANT BRIDGE. There are 200m Approaches – 2 Nos. at the Start of the Proposed Alignment to the Start of the First Foundation (Abutment A1), followed by Foundation Piers and second approach from Last Foundation (Abutment A2) to the End of the Proposed Alignment.

The Second Bridge denoted as Bridge No. 58, which is a RUB, is located after Abutment A2, on the Existing Village Road of Kukarwada Village. There is a Proposed Guide Bund Alignment, which is elliptical and located near A1 Abutment Side. For Clarity, we can understand that A1 Abutment is on Ankleshwar Side near Sarfuddin Village and A2 Abutment is on Bharuch Side near Kukarwada Village.

The Chainages of Bridge No. 57 and 58 as per Contractual Data are as below:

question: What factors contributed to the delays in casting and sinking activities in the construction project affected by the August 2019 and August 2020 floods and COVID-19 guidelines?
ground_truth: The delays in casting and sinking activities in the construction project were contributed by the aftermath of the August 2019 and August 2020 floods, which caused damage to constructions, rebar yards, and required cleaning and reworks. Additionally, lower productivity due to COVID-19 guidelines and less manpower also contributed to the delays.

question: What impact did the physical and logistical restricted access have on the Contractor's ability to start underground works for the CMRL Corridor 4 Phase 2 project?
ground_truth: The Contractor's inability to start underground works was directly caused by the lack of access to the designated section. As a result of the restricted access, the Contractor experienced significant delays in commencing underground construction activities. This had a cascading effect on the project timeline, leading to potential disruptions in project milestones and overall completion.

is required to validate that the originally designed smoke contro! system accomplishes the following performance criteria from NFPA 92: 1. Maintain a minimum pressure difference of 0.05-in.wg. (12.5-Pa) across the smoke barriers 2. Limit the maximum door opening force to 30-Ibs (133-N) for all doors (doors between smoke

zones, doors into stairwells, doors to all rooms connected to the corridor within the fire/zone)

The simplified spreadsheet calculations that were submitted by the design Engineer are not industry standard and are not capable of accurately assessing the complex leakage paths, interacting smoke control systems, wind forces, outdoor temperature, stack effect, and other factors that will impact the performance of the smoke control system on this project. Using software such as CONTAM or other network models is industry standard for this level of complexity and this system type. The spreadsheet calculations submitted by the design Engineer do not account for major parameters, have flawed fundamental assumptions, and have unrealistic final results. Thus, the calculations are neither reliable

nor accurate and cannot be used to justify the system.

Errors in the Submitted Smoke Control Calculations from the Design Engineer

A summary of the calculation flaws within ZONE 1, FIFTH FLOOR is listed below, the other zones have similar comments:

The submitted calculations do not account for wind pressure that will be present and affect pressure levels in the building — this is required to be considered in the calculations per NFPA 92.

The submitted calculations do not account for stack effect across the height of the building — this is required to be considered in the calculations per NFPA 92.

The submitted calculations do not account for ambient outdoor temperatures of the project location that will affect pressure levels in the building — this is required to be considered in the calculations per NFPA 92.

The submitted calculations have flawed fundamental assumptions such as:

¢ Incorrectly assumes that all airflow in a fire/smoke zone will only flow through the cracks of 3 total doors between the stairwells and adjacent fire/smoke zones (page 18 of 326). Does not account for the airflow that will escape the fire/smoke zone through the exterior walls, floor, roof, elevator shafts, interior smoke barrier walls, etc. - which are major factors required to be included in the calculations.

¢ Incorrectly assumes that 100% of the airflow quantity for the stairwell pressurization system will flow through the cracks of the single door within the fire/smoke zone. Does,

not account for the airflow that will escape the stairwell through the exterior walls, roof,

Page 2 of 6

W: www amanfe

Ts +568 2407 6743 E: info@amanfec.com

Oman | KSA | UAE

Aman

Engineering

doors of all other levels that the stairwell serves, etc. - which are major factors required to be included in the calculations.

The submitted calculations show that the pressure will be 17,765.48 [Pa] within ZONE 1 when it is fire/smoke zone (page 18 of 326), which is not possible for a smoke control system or fan static pressure to produce and is well beyond a reasonable pressure estimate. The maximum allowable pressure is around 90 [Pa] per NFPA 92 (depending on the door characteristics) — so the submitted calculations are over 170 times (17,000%) greater than code-maximum pressure. Thus, this one example shows the errors in the calculations are to such an extent, that Aman is not able accept them as reliable calculations to justify the smoke control system.

The submitted calculation incorrectly calculates the opening force of the door between zones (page 19 of 326). The assumption that the pressure will be 18.4 [Pa] at the door contradicts the 17,765.48 [Pa] value calculated above. The pressure that the door between zones experiences will be the sum of the negative pressure in the fire zone and the positive pressure in the adjacent zone. However, there are no calculations submitted for the pressure in the adjacent zone. The submitted calculations only list the airflow in adjacent ZONE 2 is given, however the pressure, not just the airflow, in ZONE 2 is required to calculate door opening forces.

The submitted calculation incorrectly calculates the opening force of the stairwell door (page 19 of 326). The assumption that the pressure will be 42.3 [Pa] at the door contradicts the 17,765.48 [Pa

] value calculated above. The pressure that the stairwell door experiences will be the sum of the negative pressure provided by the smoke control system and the positive Pressure created by the stairwell pressurization system. However, the calculations are incorrectly estimating the interaction of the stairwell pressurization system and smoke control system.

There are other flaws in the calculations, but those listed above are enough to show that the

spread sheet calculations are not equipped to properly assess this smoke control system.

question: What led to delays and costs in CMRL Corridor 4 Phase 2?
ground_truth: The delays and costs in CMRL Corridor 4 Phase 2 were primarily caused by the delayed handover of the elevated viaduct sections, which hindered the progress of track works. The delays in providing access to these sections postponed the work and disrupted the Contractor's planned construction sequence, resulting in time and financial losses. Additionally, many of the sections handed over contained unresolved snag points or were occupied by other contractors, causing frequent disruptions, costly resource shifts, extended work schedules, and a significant negative impact on overall Project efficiency.

213. The above summarized contract Clauses and detailed chronology of events confirm that under the Contract, Contractor is entitled to Extension of Time of 514 days on account of Sub-Clause 2.1 (Right of access to Site), and Sub-Clause 8.4 (b) for Extension of time.

6.2.2 DE-02 - DELAY IN TRACK WORKS DUE TO PIECEMEAL & PARTIAL HAND OVER

OF ELEVATED VIADUCT

a) Introduction

Privileged and Confidential

Page 70 of 116

Contract Package: CMRL CORRIDOR 4 PHASE 2 Contractor’s Interim Submission for Extension of Time

214. The progress of track works has been significantly hindered due to the delayed handover of the elevated viaduct sections, as specified in the detailed work program. According to the Contract, key sections of the viaduct were to be handed over on particular dates, and the Contractor had planned its activities and construction sequence accordingly. However, the delays in providing access to these sections have not only postponed the work but also disrupted the Contractor’s planned construction sequence, resulting in both time and financial losses. Additionally, many of the sections that were handed over contained unresolved snag points or remained occupied by other contractors. These delays have caused frequent disruptions, leading to costly resource shifts, extended work schedules, and a significant negative impact on overall Project efficiency. b) Contractual Entitlement

215. Clause 8.4 (Extension of Time for Completion) of GCC states that:

The Contractor shall be entitled subject to Sub-Clause 20.1 [Contractor’s Claims] to an extension of the Time for Completion if and to the extent that completion for the purposes of Sub-Clause 10.1 [Taking Over of the Works and Sections] is or will be delayed by any of the following causes:

(b) a cause of delay giving an entitlement to extension of time under a Sub-Clause of these Conditions,

(e)any delay, impediment or prevention caused by or attributable to the Employer, the Employer's Personnel, or the Employer's other contractors

216. Clause 2.1(Right of Access to the Site) of General condition of the Contract states that:

The Employer shall give the Contractor right of access to, and possession of, all parts of the site within the time stated in the Contract Data.

3.6. SCOPE OF WORK

56. Scope of Works include Supply, installation, testing, and commissioning of standard gauge track works, including all associated works in both underground and elevated sections between Light House Station and Poonamallee Bypass Station, as well as the Poonamallee Depot, in Corridor- 4 of the Chennai Metro Rail Project - Phase 2.

57. The total section length spans approximately 28.62 route kilometers, featuring 18 elevated stations, 12 underground stations, and 1 depot located at Poonamallee. The track is standard gauge (1435 mm). Both the elevated and underground sections utilize a ballast less plinth/slab track system, while the depot is equipped with a ballasted track.

58. Procurement of track materials, including rails, turnouts, fastenings, ballast, sleepers, MSS, check rails, spares, etc., along with the execution of works, falls under the scope of the track contractor.

61. The Defect Liability Period pursuant to Sub-Clause 1.1.3.7 of the conditions of the Contract is 730 days38 after the Completion Date.

question: How have access delays and FBW openings affected CMRL Corridor 4 Phase 2, and what contract measures address this?
ground_truth: Access delays have significantly hindered the progress of track works in the underground sections, causing disruptions to the Contractor's planned sequence of operations and leading to time and financial losses. The delays in handover have resulted in costly resource shifts, extended work schedules, and a negative impact on overall Project efficiency. Contract measures addressing this include Clause 8.4 (Extension of Time for Completion), which entitles the Contractor to an extension of time if completion is delayed by causes such as delays attributable to the Employer or the Employer's personnel. Clause 2.1 (Right of Access to the Site) also states that the Employer must provide the Contractor with access to the site within the time stated in the Contract Data.

251. The above summarized contract Clauses & detailed chronology of events confirm that under the Contract Contractor is entitled to Extension of Time of 550 days on account of Sub-Clause 2.1 (Right of access to Site), Sub-Clause 8.4 (b) & (e) for Extension of time.

6.2.3 DE-03- DELAY IN PROVIDING ACCESS OF UNDERGROUD SECTION

a) Introduction

252. The progress of track works in the underground sections has been significantly hindered due to delays in the handover of these sections, as outlined in the Detailed Work Program. As per the contract, key underground sections were to be handed over on specific dates, and the Contractor had scheduled its activities and construction sequence accordingly. However, the delays in granting access to these areas have not only postponed the work but also disrupted the Contractor's planned sequence of operations, causing both time and financial losses. Furthermore, many of the sections that were eventually handed over contained unresolved snag points or were still occupied by other contractors. These delays in handover have caused frequent disruptions, leading to costly resource shifts, extended work schedules, and a considerable negative impact on overall Project efficiency. b) Contractual Entitlement

253. Clause 8.4 (Extension of Time for Completion) of GCC states that:

The Contractor shall be entitled subject to Sub-Clause 20.1 [Contractor’s Claims] to an extension of the Time for Completion if and to the extent that completion for the purposes of Sub-Clause 10.1 [Taking Over of the Works and Sections] is or will be delayed by any of the following causes:

(b) a cause of delay giving an entitlement to extension of time under a Sub-Clause of these Conditions,

Privileged and Confidential

(e)any delay, impediment or prevention caused by or attributable to the Employer, the Employer's Personnel, or the Employer's other contractors

254. Clause 2.1(Right of Access to the Site) of General condition of the Contract states that:

The Employer shall give the Contractor right of access to, and possession of, all parts of the site within the time stated in the Contract Data.

If no such time is stated in the Contract data, the Employer shall give the Contractor right of access to, and possession of the Site as per the programme submitted under Clause 8.3.

For the purpose of reckoning the delay, the latter among the dates mentioned in the Appendix- 2A and the date by which the Contractor required such track length in the approved programme shall be considered.

question: How did delays at P309-P310 affect the Track Contractor's timeline for plinth casting in CMRL Corridor 4 Phase 2?
ground_truth: The handover of the viaduct segment at P309-P310 on 2nd September 2023 was not conducive to immediate progress. Critical works such as grouting of bearings and the issuance of ICCF-10 by the Civil Contractor were completed only on 1st February 2024, causing over five months of delay for the Track Contractor to proceed with plinth casting.
contexts:
Contract Package: CMRL CORRIDOR 4 PHASE 2 Contractor’s Interim Submission for Extension of Time

Engineer/Employer to meet key access dates as outlined in the Contract Agreement. The Contractor clarified that despite mobilizing resources as per the schedule, several key areas were not handed over on time, resulting in demobilization of resources and financial loss. Additionally, some of the partially handed over sections have been damaged by the civil contractor, who has been allowed to use these areas for vehicle movement, further delaying progress.

224. On 12 October 2023100, the Engineer informed the Contractor that the Contractor chief interface manager rejected the handover statement from the civil contractor after a joint survey between P no. 329 to 352 due to snag points. However, the Engineer’s review found the levels acceptable, and the snag points will not affect rail lifting, welding, or track works. The Engineer advised to withdraw the rejection and address the snag points based on priority, following the Contract's Interface Management guidelines.

225. The Contractor on 19 October 2023101, intimated that with regard to the taking over of the viaduct section from P329 to P352, the same section is filled with snag points and hence intimated the Employer that, the shear connectors spacing and height are not matching as per drawing, If any failure on account of above, the Contractor is not responsible, and the additional work incurred like surface levelling of deck slab, shear connectors cutting, chipping, straightening of shear connectors, repairing of cracks in U-girder etc., will be worked out and this estimate will be submitted to the Employer for payment purpose.

226. On 06 Nov 2023102, the Engineer acknowledged that only 1,527 track meters were handed over on both up and down lines, and even this was in three separate locations on staggered dates under ISF No. 008/KEC (04 February 2023) and ISF No. 009 (30 September 2023). This phased handover caused disruptions to the Track Contractor’s ability to plan and execute work efficiently. The letter confirms that the handover was provided under shared access conditions, which inherently limited the contractor’s ability to work freely and progress at an optimal pace. Shared access often leads to interruptions and additional coordination challenges, which are beyond the Track Contractor’s control.

227. Despite the Project schedule, the significant delay in handing over sections—spanning from February 2023 to September 2023—indicates the Employer’s inability to ensure that the Civil Contractor met its obligations. This delay disrupted the Track Contractor’s ability to adhere to the planned timelines for track work.

228. The Contractor on 1 February 2024103, intimated the Employer that a grouting issue was identified for bearings at viaduct segments P309-P310. Even though the section was handed over for track work on 02 September 2023 after clearing snag points, there were pending grouting works. a) Introduction

252. The progress of track works in the underground sections has been significantly hindered due to delays in the handover of these sections, as outlined in the Detailed Work Program. As per the contract, key underground sections were to be handed over on specific dates, and the Contractor had scheduled its activities and construction sequence accordingly. However, the delays in granting access to these areas have not only postponed the work but also disrupted the Contractor's planned sequence of operations, causing both time and financial losses. Furthermore, many of the sections that were eventually handed over contained unresolved snag points or were still occupied by other contractors. These delays in handover have caused frequent disruptions, leading to costly resource shifts, extended work schedules, and a considerable negative impact on overall Project efficiency. b) Contractual Entitlement

question: How do critical delays by the Contractor impact the Chennai Metro Rail Project's timeline and EOT rights?
ground_truth: The context does not mention any critical delays caused by the Contractor. Instead, it highlights that the delays are not attributable to the Contractor and are beyond its reasonable control. Therefore, the Contractor is entitled to an Extension of Time (EOT) for the delays which are not its fault.
contexts:
. This Report is submitted in connection with the Contractor’s request for an extension of time (EOT) for the completion of the “Supply, Installation, Testing, and Commissioning of Track Works” for the Chennai Metro Rail Project, Corridor 4 (C4 - TRK – 01). The Contractor, is responsible for executing the Project between Lighthouse Station and Poonamallee Bypass Station, including the Poonamallee Depot. The primary objective of this Report is to demonstrate the Contractor’s entitlement to the EOT based on the delays experienced up to the cut-off date of 31 July 2024.

26. The total length of the Project involves approximately 28.62 Route Kilometers, including both elevated and underground sections. The Project, valued at INR 337.76 crores, commenced on 14 February 2022, with a planned completion date of 05 January 2026. However, several delays have significantly impacted progress, necessitating this request for an extension.

27. The Contractor has encountered numerous delay events, primarily stemming from factors beyond its control, which have severely impacted the planned schedule. The main delay events considered in this analysis are summarized as follows and detailed in Part 6 of the Report:

28. Delay in providing access to the depot area19: The Contractor faced significant delays in accessing critical areas within the depot, including the test track, open area, stabling bay lines, inspection bay lines, and repair bay lines. The piecemeal and unorganized handover of these sections resulted in the Project disruptions and delayed activities. Despite multiple notifications,

full access to these areas was not provided in a timely manner, impacting the planned execution sequence.

29. Delay in track works due to piecemeal & partial handover of elevated viaduct20: Delays in the handover of the elevated viaduct sections resulted in prolonged interruptions in the track works. The Contractor was unable to carry out continuous work due to the incomplete access provided by the civil contractors.

30. Delay in providing access to the underground section21: Similar to the depot area, the Contractor experienced delays in accessing critical portions of the underground section, causing further disruptions to the construction timeline.

31. Delays due to variation/additional works22: Various variations and additional works requested by the Employer introduced further delays in the execution process. The Contractor has documented these changes and their impact on the overall timeline.

32. However, it is an undisputed position that the Project has been suffering inordinate delays since its inception due to various reasons not attributable to the Contractor. The Project has been critically affected by some major delays including but not limited to delay in providing access, delay due to variation/additional works etc.

33. The Contractor through various letters, e-mail correspondences, MOMs and monthly progress reports, has consistently been raising the issues which are critical to the Project and hampering the Project progress. The Contractor is therefore of the opinion that it is entitled for an Extension of Time for Completion, for the delays which are not attributable to it and were not envisaged at the time of bidding.

34. This Report covers a detailed analysis of those delay events which are beyond the reasonable control of the Contractor and affected the Project progress during the course of the Project i.e., from the date of Commencement 14 February 2022 till 31 July 2024 (the cut-off date for this Report). This Report serves as an interim request and entitles the Contractor for an Extension of Time for Completion without levying any Liquidated Damages.

35. The Contractor has employed the Impacted As Planned (IAP) methodology to conduct a detailed delay analysis in line with industry standards and best practices. This methodology has been utilized

to identify and evaluate the delay events that have significantly impacted the progress of the Project.

36. As part of this analysis, the Contractor has incorporated the relevant delay fragnets into the baseline schedule to assess the extent of the delays. These delay events have been determined to

be outside the Contractor's reasonable control and are not attributable to any actions or omissions on the Contractor's part.

37. The Contractor remains committed to fulfilling its contractual obligations and has made all reasonable efforts to mitigate the impact of these delay events. This submission, supported by the IAP methodology, forms the basis for the Contractor's request for an Extension of Time (EOT) in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Contract. The detailed explanation of the delay analysis methodology has been explained in Part-5 of this report. It is to note that, each delay event is inserted in the detailed work programme to assess the individual impact of each delay event over the previous events.



If a shift is noted in the scheduled completion date of the Project Milestones after insertion and the impact of a particular delay event, the delay impact is considered to be critical. The additional impact the delay events make may be noted and then the procedure is repeated for the next delay event.

39. However, if no shift is noted, the delay impact is considered to be non-critical. Again, the

procedure is repeated for the next delay event.

40. The Contractor is of the opinion that it is entitled to an additional cost for the prolonged period and other losses which are not attributable to the Contractor and were not envisaged at the time of bidding.

41.

It is to be noted that various delays and disruption events in the Works resulted/ resulting in losses and non-recovery of cost expenses being incurred to the Contractor.

42. The cumulative effect of these delays has led to significant disruptions in the planned execution of the Project. As of 31 July 2024, the physical progress achieved stands at 41.19%23, while the financial progress is recorded at 24.55%24. These delays have impacted the Project’s critical path, extending the Project completion date by 650 days, which is reflected in this submission.

43. The Contractor has adhered to the contractual provisions under the General Conditions of Contract (GCC), including clauses related to delayed access (Clause 2.1) and extension of time (Clause 8.4). Despite the Contractor's efforts to mitigate delays and proceed with the available work, the lack of timely access and other disruptions has affected the Project’s schedule. The Contractor is, therefore, entitled to an extension of time of 650 days, along with compensation for the additional costs incurred due to these delays.

191. The above summarized contract Clauses & detailed chronology of events confirm that under the Contract Contractor is entitled to Extension of Time of 335 days on account of Sub-Clause 2.1 (Right of access to Site), Sub-Clause 8.4 (b) for Extension of time.

6.2.1.4 DE-01-04: DELAY IN PROVIDING ACCESS OF STABLING BAY LINE

a) Introduction

192. The Contractor experienced substantial delays in gaining access to the Stabling Bay Lines (SBL) due to non-sequential and partial handovers by the civil contractor. These disruptions significantly impacted the planned execution of track works, particularly in the depot area, where access to critical sections was delayed. The detailed work plan, submitted on 07 September 2023, anticipated the full handover of the stabling bay lines by 26 March 2023, allowing for efficient and continuous work. However, this timeline was not adhered to, with the final handover of key sections occurring as late as July 2024.

193. The delayed access to the SBL areas, coupled with the incomplete civil works, hindered the Contractor’s ability to proceed according to the planned sequence of activities. As a result, rail welding and other critical works were delayed, leading to increased costs, operational inefficiencies, and significant disruptions to the Project’s overall timeline. Despite efforts to mitigate these issues, the Contractor faced substantial challenges in meeting the Project deadlines, as the sequence of construction had to be frequently altered due to the late handover of various SBL sections. b) Contractual Entitlement

194. Clause 2.1(Right of Access to the Site) of General condition of the Contract states that:

The Employer shall give the Contractor right of access to, and possession of, all parts of the site within the time stated in the Contract Data.

If no such time is stated in the Contract data, the Employer shall give the Contractor right of access to, and possession of the Site as per the programme submitted under Clause 8.3.

question: How did fragmented handovers and unresolved issues impact CMRL Corridor 4's progress?
ground_truth: The fragmented handovers and unresolved snag points severely disrupted the Contractor's workflow, leading to costly resource shifts, delays in work completion, and idling of equipment and manpower. The limited sections made available for work, such as the mere 1.95 km out of the handed-over 9.42 km, delayed plinth casting and track installation. Moreover, the ongoing occupation of sections by other contractors and unaddressed snag points led to further delays, as materials such as welded rail panels could not be fully deployed.
contexts:
Critical works such as grouting of bearings and the issuance of ICCF-10 by the Civil Contractor were completed only on 1st February 2024, causing over five months of delay for the Track Contractor to proceed with plinth casting

232. On 25 March 2024106, the Engineer issued a formal communication to the Contractor highlighting significant concerns over delays in achieving key dates of elevated structure and test track with substantial completion of work. The Engineer emphasized that the Contractor’s inability to meet these milestones violates the requirements outlined in the Contract and exposes them to delay damages as per the applicable clauses, including GCC and PCC provisions. The communication concluded with a reminder that further non-compliance could invoke contractual penalties, stressing the need for urgent corrective measures.

233. On 26 March 2024107, the Engineer issued the Contractor the notice for the shortfall in the works of elevated section.

234. On 10 April 2024108, the Contractor notified the Employer about unresolved issues, including the closure of snag points and the failure to remove shuttering and other construction materials from the handed-over site, which caused disruptions to the planned works.

235. On 18 April 2024109, the Contractor notified the Employer that the availability of work fronts on the viaduct section did not align with the agreed contractual terms. The viaduct sections were handed over to the Contractor in fragmented portions, disrupting the continuity of work.

This implicitly validates the Contractor's concerns about delayed handover affecting their performance. This phased approach has likely disrupted the Contractor’s planning and execution.

237. The Engineer points out that plinth concreting began only in February 2024, despite the handover starting in February 2023. This delay indirectly highlights that the conditions or access provided to the Contractor may not have been conducive for timely commencement of work.

238. On 19 July 2024111, the Contractor notified the Employer of a primary breach of Contract due to the failure to meet the agreed key dates for the handover of civil works, which are critical for the progress of track work. As per the contract, 51.673 km of the section (10.526 km in the Depot and 41.147 km in the Elevated Corridor) was to be handed over. However, only 9.42 km of the Elevated Corridor and 7.0 km of the Depot have been handed over, and even then, with shared access, numerous snag points, and in a piecemeal manner. Of the 9.42 km handed over, only 1.95 km was suitable for plinth casting, with the rest hindered by unresolved snag points. Critically, no section has been provided with hindrance-free access, severely impacting the progress of the works and contributing to delays beyond our control. d) Cause & Effect Analysis

242. The primary cause of the delays in the construction of the elevated section and the progress of track works is the piecemeal and partial handover of key sections and not as per the dates agreed in Detailed Work Programme, contrary to the Contract's stipulation for full and hindrance-free access of the sections as per IWP. Although the Contractor was prepared with materials and had mobilized resources to proceed as per the schedule, critical areas were handed over in fragmented stretches, each riddled with unresolved snag points. These issues were compounded by civil contractors occupying sections post-handover, preventing the Contractor from efficiently utilizing the work fronts. Furthermore, critical civil works, such as plinth casting and alignment preparations, were delayed or incomplete, restricting the Contractor’s ability to proceed with track laying.

243. The fragmented handovers and unresolved snag points severely disrupted the Contractor's workflow, leading to costly resource shifts, delays in work completion, and idling of equipment and manpower. The limited sections made available for work, such as the mere 1.95 km out of the handed-over 9.42 km, delayed plinth casting and track installation.
